items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.htmlBody:
﻿Hello mushroom lovers,

We had a marvelous tour of BOSLab, the country’s first community biolab. C.H.A.M.P. members learned about opportunities for using equipment such as PCR thermal cyclers, fluorescence plate readers, incubators, and autoclaves. We discussed the possibilities for DNA barcoding/IT tagging, advanced microscopy, and a range of other art and bio-engineering projects.

We also explored creating C.H.A.M.P. / BOSLab co-branded workshops, including sessions on cultivating mushrooms, hosting a crash course on microscopy and staining, and presenting talks and film screenings.

Lastly, we touched on outdoor programming such as using “Lil Lab”—a laboratory on wheels for conducting science au plein air!

If any of this excites you, send your thoughts to the C.H.A.M.P. suggestion box!

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/

Dr. Wendy Pouliot, neurobiologist and BOSLab President, with the 1940s windshield-wiper display cabinet she converted into “Lil Lab,” a mobile research station outfitted with a trinocular stereo microscope. Underwritten by grants from the Massachusetts Cultural Council.

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Call for ideas: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion
items.subject: Call for ideas: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion
items.htmlBody:
﻿Hello sub-group of Mushroom lovers,

I know all of you - to varying degrees -  from our fledging and inchoate fungi affinity group, C.H.A.M.P.

Larry Millman, included here, and I meet regularly to discuss possible fungi-related projects, and I wanted to reach out to a wider group to cast seeds for more ideas.

This email grows out of the email below which I just received yesterday from the New England Botanic Garden. As you’ll see, they are receptive to host / promote / and collaborate on mycology-themed content we develop.

I’m not fond of group e-mails, but I’m taking a chance this one will fertilize discussion between us and beyond.

I’d like to be the point person with the Botanic Garden at this early stage, so please share your thoughts with me directly.

Looking forward to see what  incubates. My hope is that we can germinate viable content rooted in your respective fields!

Jon Applefield
(917) 957-5152

Ps: To be reductive parenthetically, “we” on this email thread are roughly: me (an art historian); Larry (ethnographer, writer, mycologist); Cody, Jula, and David (bio scientists - [sorry for lack of specifics]); Char (writer, myco-beverage entrepreneur, end-of-life doula); Amanda (Worcester-based mycologist- cultivator, entrepreneur); KieuLy and Sean (Worcester-based enthusiast and filmmakers). 

Begin forwarded message:

From: Alyson Prokop <aprokop@nebg.org>
Date: January 8, 2026 at 5:45:30 PM EST
To: Jonathan Applefield <jonathan_applefield@hotmail.com>
Subject: RE: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion

﻿

Hi Jon,

 

Thank you so much for reaching out—and for sharing the April 29 mushroom pigment program with your community. I’m delighted to hear it resonated, and I appreciate you including it on your calendar.

 

All three ideas you’ve outlined absolutely resonate with me. I’m particularly interested in exploring May and June as potential windows for collaboration, though I’m very open to other times of year as well, depending on the format and scope.

 

The documentary screening and contextual talk sound especially compelling, and a guided mycology foray—if structured to align with our site guidelines—could be a wonderful public-facing offering – June would be perfect as we have a monthly speaker series, and I have yet to find a speaker for this month!

 

I’d be happy to set up a time to talk through possibilities, goals, and logistics, and to explore what a collaborative partnership (rather than a simple venue rental) could look like.

 

Let me know what your availability looks like in the coming weeks, and we can take it from there.

 

With thanks,

Aly

 

Alyson Prokop

Manager of Adult Education

she/her

 

New England Botanic Garden at Tower Hill

508.869.6111 x149
nebg.org

 

 

From: Jonathan Applefield <jonathan_applefield@hotmail.com>
Sent: December 15, 2025 2:11 PM
To: Alyson Prokop <aprokop@nebg.org>
Subject: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion

 

CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

 

Hello Allison,

 

I just got off the phone with Liz the register there. I am Jon Applefield - one of the organizers of a new group of mushroom enthusiast in the Boston area. Our group is C.H.A.M.P. (Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion). Many of us are involved in the Boston Mycology Club, but this fall we started this group to foster citizen science and greater public outreach (rather than serving a niche of specialists).

 

I’m writing for a few purposes. First, I just wanted to let you know we listed your event on April 29 regarding dying with mushroom pigments on our website’s calendar. Looks like a wonderful program.

 

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/calendar/

 

Second, we’re in the planning phases of screening a fascinating ethnographic documentary on the mushroom culture of a group of Arctic peoples. One of our members, Lawrence Millman, is an expert on the Far North, having traveled dozens of times to Siberia, the Canadian Arctic, Greenland, and Norway. He is going to set the film into context, but I’m the logistics person.  In this regard, I was exploring the idea of NEBG as a venue (not so much as a rental site, but a collaborative partner).

 

Finally, after speaking with Liz, I was curious if - with both parties consent - I might facilitate a mycology foray at your site guided by Mr. Millman. This would be open to the public and follow whatever guidelines you see fit.

 

Let me know if any of this resonates with you. Our timelines are not that rigid, but I’m of the opinion that it’s always best to get things on the calendar when the inspiration is highest!

 

All the best,

Jon
